texts.definition: Fixed amounts of game time needed for an event to have its main effect.
markups: <style="Definition">Fixed amounts of game time needed for an event to have its main effect.</style>
Some actions performed in games do not have immediate effects. Instead, they start processes that after some given time, its <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style>, has it effect.

The construction of buildings or units in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> always takes at least one turn but most often more depending on what is built and how developed the city where the construction takes place.
The plants grown in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> take variable amount of time to mature depending on which type it is.

Calling air strikes in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> can be done quickly but it then takes some time for the actual attack to occur.

The prime choice for <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> is what event or event caused by an action should be affected. Most actions are eligible to have <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> but the pattern is most often used with actions related to <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> is related to both <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> but are not the same. If the <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> blocks players from making other actions (as for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>) this makes the actions into <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, but if players cannot make use of the actions anyway (e.g. by them being <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> spread out in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>) this becomes a non-issue. <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> does not by itself create <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> but when the actions modified by the pattern are also <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style> this creates <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> for those that wish to stop them from being completed.

<style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> are often used in conjunction with <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> so that players can plan future actions, and feel <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> is basically a way to create <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> with known parameters, and as such they provide <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> and promote <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> since players need to consider the effect of the actions will affect a future game state rather than the current one. It may also led to <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> if players cannot initiate the same action again before it is finished, and <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> if no other actions are available either. When players are kept informed of the statuses of <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style>, for example through <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>, this leads to <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>. This can also let players engage in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> to be able to do <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> between different events based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> them well.

In games with either <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay or <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Development Time</style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style>.

When combine with <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, they require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations to start and present <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to those that wish to make the actions fail.
